caption.p: Graphical representation of the end-expiratory lung volume (EELV), airway pressure and esophageal pressure as a function of the PEEP-IAP gradient. Note the marked decrease in end-expiratory lung volume (EELV) when the IAP level exceeds the programmed PEEP. The increase in airway pressure when the IAP exceeds the absolute value of PEEP may be explained by the increase in end-inspiratory esophageal pressure; however, the end-expiratory Pes remains non-responsive to the increase in IAP.
EELV - end-expiratory lung volume; PEEP - positive end-expiratory pressure; IAP - intra-abdominal pressure.
